title: GE CARESCAPE Canvas – Will Not Power On
description: Basic power troubleshooting for a GE CARESCAPE Canvas patient monitor.

steps.title: Make Sure the Monitor Has Power
instructions: Confirm the monitor is plugged into an outlet that you know is working.
If unsure, plug in another device (lamp, phone charger, etc.) to test the outlet.
If the monitor is plugged into a power strip or isolation transformer, make sure that device is also turned on.

steps.title: Check the Power Cord
instructions: Look over the power cord for cuts, fraying, bent or broken prongs.
Make sure the cord is pushed in firmly at the wall outlet and back of the monitor.

CCR.Cause: Monitor shows no power with known-working outlet and known-good power cord. No indicator lights or screen activity observed. Suspected internal power failure.
CCR.Resolution: Removed from service and sent for repair.

helpfulDetails: Final status (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: ZOLL R Series – Battery Fails Self-Test
description: Basic battery troubleshooting for a ZOLL R Series defibrillator reporting a failed self-test.

steps.title: Make Sure the Battery Is Fully Seated
instructions: Confirm the battery is installed correctly in the defibrillator.
Remove the battery and reinsert it, making sure it clicks or seats firmly into place.
A loose battery can cause self-test failures even if the battery itself is good.

steps.title: Check the Battery Contacts
instructions: Inspect the battery and device contacts for dirt or debris.
Look for corrosion or bent or damaged pins.
If safe to do so, gently clean visible debris from the contacts and reinsert the battery.
Poor contact between the battery and device can cause charging and self-test issues.

steps.title: Verify the Battery Has Been Charging
instructions: Confirm the defibrillator has been plugged into AC power when stored.
Check for any charging or status indicators that show the battery has been receiving power.
A battery that has not been charging may fail self-test due to low capacity.

steps.title: Try a Known-Good Battery (If Available)
instructions: Remove the current battery and insert a known-good battery from another unit.
Allow the unit to complete its self-test again.
This helps determine whether the issue is with the battery or the defibrillator itself.

steps.title: Observe the Self-Test Message or Indicator
instructions: Note exactly what the display or status indicator shows.
Does it say "Battery Fail"?
Does it say "Replace Battery"?
Does it fail immediately or after charging?
Even small details can help determine the cause.

CCR.Cause: Battery fails self-test after reseating and charging. Alternate battery passes self-test. Suspected failed battery pack.
CCR.Resolution: Removed battery from service and replaced with known-good battery.

helpfulDetails: Final status (battery replaced or sent for repair)

title: GE B850 – Will Not Power On
description: Basic power troubleshooting for a GE B850 patient monitor.

steps.title: Make Sure the Monitor Has Power
instructions: Confirm the monitor is plugged into an outlet that you know is working.

title: Baxter Sigma Spectrum Infusion Pump – Occlusion Alarm / Will Not Start Infusion
description: Basic troubleshooting when a Sigma Spectrum infusion pump shows an occlusion alarm and will not start infusion.

steps.title: Check the IV Set and Tubing
instructions: Make sure the tubing is properly loaded into the pump.
Confirm there are no kinks, twists, or sharp bends in the line.
Check that clamps are fully open and not blocking fluid flow.
Even a small pinch or bend can trigger an occlusion alarm.

steps.title: Inspect the Pump Door and Cassette
instructions: Ensure the cassette or disposable set is seated correctly.
Close the door fully — the pump may not start if it senses the door is ajar.
Some alarms are triggered if the cassette isn’t aligned properly.

steps.title: Check the Fluid Bag or Syringe
instructions: Make sure there is fluid in the bag or syringe.
Confirm that the tubing is primed — air in the line can sometimes trigger an occlusion alarm.

steps.title: Observe the Pump Display and Alarm
instructions: Look for any other messages on the display.
Note the color and type of alarm: Red = occlusion, Yellow = warning / low fluid.
Record what you see — this helps when documenting.

steps.title: Try a Simple Reset
instructions: Stop the pump.
Remove and reload the tubing.
Close the door and restart the pump.
If the alarm clears, the pump may resume infusion. If not, escalate.

CCR.Complaint: Pump will not start infusion; occlusion alarm displayed.
CCR.Cause: Tubing and cassette inspected, tubing free of kinks, door fully closed, fluid present. Alarm persists. Suspected internal pump sensor issue.
CCR.Resolution: Removed pump from service, labeled out of service, sent for repair or tagged for bench evaluation.

helpfulDetails: Any unusual sounds or display behavior
Final disposition (returned to service or sent for repair)
